column4: On Karmic, I realized that the wireless WPA passphrase is not hashed anymore. If I got to Passwords and Keyrings, I find that the passphrase is stored in plaintext. With Jaunty it was hashed. Is there a way to store them as hashes again?
Does anyone have any idea why Karmic does not store the hash anymore, but rather uses plaintext for passwords and keyrings?
I have do idea it did...
on Jaunty, it stored my passphrases as hash values.
but now on Karmic, it's storing them as plaintext, which anyone can see if they look over your shoulder!
yeah, I haven't looked into that, a bit slack though if it no longer encrypts/hashes things like that
I hope it gets fixed soon. I even tried deleting everything and starting from scratch, but it doesn't work.
I did a fresh install, not an upgrade.
this is a fresh install, but restored ~ from a backup, so things like keyrings are from previous install

so when you go to "Passwords and Encryption Keys" and check any item's properties, then click view password, you only see a hash value (looks like an md5sum or something) and not the plaintext password?
ahhh, yes.. those are stored 'encrypted' and only gt unlocked when you log in...
they should not be plaintext in a file anywhere
but I mean, when you try to "view" them, do they show you the actual password, or a hashed value?
it cannot be a 'hashed value', it needs the actual password to connect
for example, say you go to a friend's house, and he types in the wireless password for you. Is his password stored as a hash, and you cannot view it in plaintext ever?
this was the case with Jaunty.
hmmmm not sure.
at my cousin's house, he entered his wireless passphrase. I showed him "When I check the box to view your password, it only shows me a hash value, see?"
but now on Karmic, checking that same box will display the actual password in plaintext!
there's no security in that.. the hash value is the key, you can copy that to another computer and it will be able to connect
this is the behavior I am trying to get on Karmic.
but I can't tell anyone "his password is..." And it might even be a password used for other things too.
well, I have no idea...
